newsitem.title: JAPAN: Gold - Japan bullion market awash with gold -- traders.
newsitem.headline: Gold - Japan bullion market awash with gold -- traders.

text.p: Gold bullion is likely to remain cheaper in Tokyo than in London, centre of the global trade, at least until the end of the year, as a fall in local jewellery sales and higher output by local smelters has left Japan awash with bullion, traders said on Monday.
They added that this highly unusual discount in the Tokyo market may force some gold dealers to re-export gold and swallow shipping costs to Europe of around 50 to 60 cents per ounce.

Japan's spot bullion prices have already languished at flat to 30 cents an ounce below loco London, on a C and F basis, for more than a month, and activity on the Tokyo gold market has slowed to a trickle.
Traders said jewellery manufacturers will be able to meet a large part of their needs for the busy Christmas season from stocks built up during the year's protracted jewellery slump.

"Gold demand from the jewellery sector usually rises around this time of year ahead of the year-end gift-giving season, but we haven't seen any fresh demand," a trading house trader said. Bullion prices have been pressured from the supply side too.
Japanese smelters' gold output jumped 13.4 percent in the first eight months of this year to 83.49 tonnes, according to the Japan Mining Industry Association.
An official at the industry body attributed the rise to higher output of refined copper. Copper refining yields small amounts of gold contained in the ore as a by-product.
This trend was also reflected in Japan's trade statistics, which showed a surge in recent months in imports of ore concentrates containing copper and low levels of gold.

"Higher output of domestic gold has obviously weighed on the local bullion market. Japanese copper smelters are believed to have boosted production to take advantage of high smelting charges," an official of a bullion house said.

Some market sources said Japanese traders may be forced to re-export gold if the current supply surplus and the weaker local bullion price continue, although this would be a last resort, given high shipping costs.
The primary hope for a bounce in premiums will come when the Tokyo Commodity Exchange's December gold futures contract expires in late December.
At this time, trade houses holding short positions may be forced to buy gold in the Tokyo spot market to meet delivery requirements.

"If private investors who hold massive long positions in the December contract take deliveries at the expiry, gold bullion prices could rebound temporarily," one trader said. -- Tokyo Commodities Desk +81-3-3432-7431
